system.biography:
TitleFFF 801c Gargu-Hyeka King
Birthday10 Agrazhar 704
AppearanceAge 15, height 4’0”, heavy frame (size 4), 100 lb, pallid complexion, brown hair, black eyes.
Medical/Psyche
Size0
ArmorPlain loincloth; kurbul girdle, leather and hide boots. Kurbul ailettes from Agrikan Haragki (knight), splint vam- braces, and kurbul girdle from Laranian Erana (knight). Battleaxe.
Other Equipment
Valuables36d worth of coins, Laranian girdle (heirloom, 25d)
Notes

Biography

At the age of 15, Drogor “Bone-Splitter” became king of his gargun colony by murdering his predecessor. He gained his moniker when he messily dismembered the king and served him up as a meal to the hive.

The only thing that gargun respect is raw power. Because the gods tend to work via proxies, gargun have little reason to submit to worshiping them.

Drogor became fascinated with the human concept of the gods while observing hostilities between Laranian and Agrikan knights. He concluded that anything that inspires humans to such acts of carnage was worthy of study. To that end, Drogor commanded that his warri- ors bring back anything belonging to the gods. He has since collected all manner of religious icons and para- phernalia and keeps a chamber filled with these “god- things” in the colony’s cave complex.

Drogor was delighted when his warriors captured Lorginys, an elderly Agrikan Ulankh (mendicant priest). Lorginys was prepared to go to Balgashang as he was dragged before the gargun king. To his bewilderment, the king demanded in horrid Hârnic that he teach him about the gods.

Lorginys makes up that which he does not know, fearful that Drogor may devour him if he no longer ap- pears useful. The constant threat of death, poor nutri- tion, and mistreatment at the hands of gargun has caused the priest to slip into insanity. As a result, he fa- bricates many odd doctrines, some of which have had dreadful effects. Drogor has concluded that some hu- mans carry the power of the gods in them (such as spells and invocations) and has decided that he should have that power for himself. Roasted priests are set aside for Drogor alone, who enforces this culinary pro- hibition by devouring any offender.

HOOKS

Give Me Your Gods! Drogor ambushes the PCs. Rather than slaughtering them, he orders them in ghastly Hârnic to surrender. He wishes to plunder any religious icons, as is his due as “champion of the gods.” Clerics are spared for later torture and questioning.

A Cry for Help. Lorginys capitalizes on his captors’ inability to read by giving out “blessed scrolls for divine protection” to the gargun. The scrolls actually are pleas for help and document directions to the hive and details of its defenses. The PCs recover one such scroll.

A Bird in a Cage is Better than Two in the Bush. The PCs encounter a band of gargun carrying a crude cage holding a battered priestess of Ilvir. Will the PCs rescue a poor mendicant cleric who can only repay them with words of thanks?

Credits

This character is taken from “Friends, Foes, and Followers, Part 13” on Lythia.com (https://www.lythia.com/game_aides/fff-gargu/), by Shawn Bond, with illustrations by Richard Luscheck, and is “fanon”, a derivative work of copyrighted material by Columbia Games Inc. and N. Robin Crossby.
